rename.from: d to reproduce the result you provide
rename.to: Default argument settings to reproduce the mAPs you provide

body:
Based on the comments written in Issues, I've found the steps. Could you please check if the training procedure is right to produce the correct mAP?

1. Download the master branch and prepare for the coco dataset.
2. Download "darknet53.conv.74" to the "weight" folder
3. **Do not alter any codes in the train.py**
4. Run "python3 train.py --cfg cfg/yolov3.cfg --weights weights/darknet53.conv.74"

,which produces the following arguments:
"Namespace(accumulate=2, adam=False, arc='defaultpw', batch_size=32, bucket='', cache_images=False, cfg='cfg/yolov3.cfg', data='data/coco.data', device='', epochs=273, evolve=False, img_size=416, img_weights=False, multi_scale=False, name='', nosave=False, notest=False, prebias=False, rect=False, resume=False, transfer=False, var=None, weights='weights/darknet53.conv.74')"

Will this give us 55.4 mAP or a similar one with the input size of 416?

@hgjung3 the mAPs provided in the readme are produce by the commands in the readme, which run test.py on the darknet weights.

For latest training recommendations see https://github.com/ultralytics/yolov3/issues/310.

@hgjung3 also I believe the darknet-trained weights involved a few steps not mentioned in the publication. The latest ultralytics/yolov3 trained results are about 1% below the published results, though I believe training darknet normally will not get you to the same value either.

Also the utility of the backbone seems questionable, as the best results so far (to 273 epochs) have come without the backbone, using randomly initialized weights. Note that --multi-scale seems important too.

I think off the top of my head if you wanted to train to the best mAP, you could use the default settings but add --multi-scale, and possibly lower the positive weights on the two BCE losses, as these seem to overfit  before 273, especially the objectness loss. See https://github.com/ultralytics/yolov3/issues/453 for this specific issue. 

Note also that darknet doesn't do any loss balancing, but we were unable to get good results this way, which is why we have the current hyperparameters in place.

@glenn-jocher Thanks for your reply. So, I can summarize the situation as follows (I assume the default input size as 416):

1. The mAPs on https://github.com/ultralytics/yolov3#map were produced by the darknet weights, which means you used the weights provided by the author of YOLOv3 but used your test.py and the settings.
2. If we train the model based on the master branch, we can have similar results that are possibly a little bit lower than those of the original paper.
3. So, the best (or **reasonable**) mAPs can be yielded by your code with the following settings (w/o SPP):
`python3 train.py --cfg cfg/yolov3.cfg --multi-scale`
4. The above initializes the parameters of darknet53 randomly. So another possible option is:
`python3 train.py --cfg cfg/yolov3.cfg --weights weights/darknet53.conv.74 --multi-scale`
5. In addition to 3 and 4, #453 tells us that adjusting hyp['obj_pw'] and hyp['cls_pw'] might give us higher mAPs.
6. Generally, this code exploits the mechanisms of the original paper (Yolov2 and v3) but some parts are adjusted or added.

Please let me know if something is wrong.
And another question: In your opinion, the 237 epochs are needed for training with your code? I will do the experimnets of 3 and 4 above now but I want to save my resources (times, machines,...)

Thanks again!!

@hgjung3 yes all of those points are correct, except 237 epochs is 273 epochs, which is about 500,000 iterations on the original darknet. It's possible that different hyperparameter setting would produce better results, but we are hardware limited so we can't test out all the possibilities we'd like unfortunately.

Note that the original darknet did not use positive weights on obj and cls. One problem with tuning hyperparameters is that changes that show promise early in training may actually hurt later on (such as a higher LR), so it's hard to tune hyperparameters effectively and quickly.

@glenn-jocher Thanks for your kind response!!
Another thought on the code is that if the mAP for MS COCO cannot be reasonably reproduced with darknet53.conv.74, the mAP of PASCAL VOC 2007 may be quite lower than that of the original YOLOv2 (in my opinion). This is because the smaller number of tr. data compared to COCO may require the pretrained weights on ImageNet.

Anyway, I am waiting for the result of
`python3 train.py --cfg cfg/yolov3.cfg --weights weights/darknet53.conv.74 --multi-scale`

Thanks for this project again.

@hgjung3 hmm ok great! I don't actually have any VOC experience so I can't comment on that. We have a couple models training at 320 right now without multiscale, one default and one with positive weights set to 1. I will post the results when they finish.
@glenn-jocher This project is amazing and greatly contributes to others. I assume you will kindly post the results on a new issue or other pages, I close this. Thanks.
